question_title: Which party will win the most seats in the 2026 Nepali House of Representatives election?
summary: The 2026 Nepal House of Representatives election (March 5) features a fragmented race among NC, CPN-UML, RSP, and the newly-formed NCP. Nepali Congress is the front-runner for winning the most seats due to three key structural advantages: (1) the left vote is split between CPN-UML and NCP, giving NC an enormous advantage in FPTP constituencies (165 of 275 seats); (2) NC has new energized leadership under Gagan Thapa and just won the most seats in the January 2026 National Assembly election; (3) anti-incumbency sentiment targets CPN-UML (Oli was PM during Gen Z protests). However, RSP with the hugely popular Balen Shah as PM candidate and post-Gen Z momentum (60% of surveyed voters want new parties) has a credible shot at a major surge. CPN-UML retains strong organizational depth but faces headwinds. The NCP merger consolidates leftist forces but is untested.

factors.description: Left vote split between CPN-UML and NCP benefits NC in FPTP constituencies - same dynamic that helped NC win most seats in 2022 despite lower PR vote share
NC has deep organizational infrastructure across all 165 constituencies and new leadership under Gagan Thapa
Anti-incumbency against Oli/CPN-UML - Oli was PM when forced to resign during Gen Z protests
RSP has Balen Shah (hugely popular youth figure) as PM candidate and is the main beneficiary of Gen Z movement
Voter survey shows ~60% want to seek new parties, suggesting significant appetite for change that could benefit RSP
FPTP system structurally favors established parties with deep local networks - new parties historically struggle to convert popular support into FPTP wins
NCP merger of 10 leftist parties (excluding CPN-UML) could consolidate communist votes but is a new untested entity
RSP's Rabi Lamichhane has legal issues (out on bail for cooperative fraud) and Gen Z activists already criticizing party's PR list
NC won most seats in January 2026 National Assembly election - recent signal of organizational strength
